title: Pride and Prejudice
author: Austen, Jane
rationale: Manners, class, marriage markets; strong clustering for social mobility and gender constraint.

title: Sense and Sensibility
author: Austen, Jane
rationale: Emotion vs restraint; family economics and reputation themes.

title: Great Expectations
author: Dickens, Charles
rationale: Class aspiration, guilt, transformation; bridges crime, identity, and social critique clusters.

title: A Tale of Two Cities
author: Dickens, Charles
rationale: Revolution, sacrifice, mob politics; connects to war/political upheaval clusters.

title: Bleak House
author: Dickens, Charles
rationale: Institutional critique (law), fog-of-bureaucracy themes; ideal for governance/justice clusters.

title: Jane Eyre
author: Brontë, Charlotte
rationale: Autonomy, morality, desire vs duty; strong gender/constraint + identity themes.

title: Wuthering Heights
author: Brontë, Emily
rationale: Obsession, isolation, revenge; connects to psychological torment clusters.

title: Middlemarch
author: Eliot, George
rationale: Marriage, vocation, reform politics; high thematic density across ethics and society.

title: Vanity Fair
author: Thackeray, William Makepeace
rationale: Ambition, hypocrisy, social climbing; strengthens satire + class clusters.

title: The Woman in White
author: Collins, Wilkie
rationale: Identity, deception, legal confinement; bridges mystery with social constraint themes.

title: North and South
author: Gaskell, Elizabeth Cleghorn
rationale: Industrial class conflict, labor/capital; anchors social critique and work/life themes.

title: Tess of the d'Urbervilles
author: Hardy, Thomas
rationale: Fate, sexuality, judgment; connects morality, gender, rural life clusters.

title: The Mayor of Casterbridge
author: Hardy, Thomas
rationale: Pride, downfall, community; complements tragedy and reputation clusters.

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
author: Wilde, Oscar
rationale: Hedonism, corruption, identity; gothic + moral philosophy bridge work.

title: The Hound of the Baskervilles
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan
rationale: Rationalism vs superstition; detective logic links to science/unknown clusters.

title: Moby Dick
author: Melville, Herman
rationale: Obsession, nature, metaphysics; bridges wilderness, madness, and the sublime.

title: Adventures of Huckleberry Finn
author: Twain, Mark
rationale: Race, freedom, moral growth; key for identity and social critique clusters.

title: The Scarlet Letter
author: Hawthorne, Nathaniel
rationale: Shame, law, community judgment; overlaps gender constraint and moral psychology.

title: The House of the Seven Gables
author: Hawthorne, Nathaniel
rationale: Ancestral guilt, property, decay; gothic-inflected American history themes.

title: The Great Gatsby
author: Fitzgerald, F. Scott
rationale: Wealth, desire, disillusionment; sharp class/mobility themes in modern America.

title: The Call of the Wild
author: London, Jack
rationale: Wilderness, instinct, domination; connects frontier survival with animality themes.

title: White Fang
author: London, Jack
rationale: Civilization vs wild, violence, belonging; complements Call of the Wild for nature clusters.

title: The Red Badge of Courage
author: Crane, Stephen
rationale: Fear, courage, war psychology; anchors war/aftermath clusters.

title: The Awakening
author: Chopin, Kate
rationale: Desire, autonomy, social pressure; strong gender constraint themes.

title: The Age of Innocence
author: Wharton, Edith
rationale: Social codes, marriage, status; complements Austen/Dickens class clusters cross-era.

title: Ethan Frome
author: Wharton, Edith
rationale: Constraint, duty, rural poverty; tight tragedy for isolation/entrapment clusters.

title: Little Women
author: Alcott, Louisa May
rationale: Domestic life, ambition, gender roles; strong family/constraint vocabulary.

title: The Jungle
author: Sinclair, Upton
rationale: Labor, corruption, capitalism; anchors industrial exploitation clusters.

title: Sister Carrie
author: Dreiser, Theodore
rationale: Urban ambition, desire, social mobility; bridges labor and class themes.

title: Walden
author: Thoreau, Henry David
rationale: Self-reliance, nature, dissent; bridges philosophy with American wilderness.

title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass
author: Douglass, Frederick
rationale: Freedom, violence, literacy; strengthens oppression/liberation thematic domain.

title: Crime and Punishment
author: Dostoevsky, Fyodor
rationale: Guilt, redemption, moral reasoning; core psychological torment cluster.

title: The Brothers Karamazov
author: Dostoevsky, Fyodor
rationale: Faith, doubt, responsibility; dense ethical and existential themes.

title: Notes from Underground
author: Dostoevsky, Fyodor
rationale: Alienation, spite, consciousness; high-signal existential vocabulary.

title: The Idiot
author: Dostoevsky, Fyodor
rationale: Innocence, society, nihilism; bridges morality and social critique.

title: War and Peace
author: Tolstoy, Leo
rationale: History, war, family, meaning; anchors war/aftermath + philosophy clusters.

title: Anna Karenina
author: Tolstoy, Leo
rationale: Desire, duty, society; strong cross-link to Austen/Wharton social constraint.

title: Resurrection
author: Tolstoy, Leo
rationale: Justice, repentance, prison system; bridges law, ethics, and social reform.

title: Fathers and Sons
author: Turgenev, Ivan
rationale: Generational conflict, nihilism; connects ideology and family themes.

title: Dead Souls
author: Gogol, Nikolai
rationale: Bureaucracy, greed, satire; complements Dickens/Thackeray social critique.

title: A Hero of Our Time
author: Lermontov, Mikhail

title: Frankenstein
author: Shelley, Mary

title: Dracula
author: Stoker, Bram
rationale: Contagion, sexuality, invasion; strong fear/otherness cluster.

title: Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
rationale: Duality, addiction, respectability; psychological + morality bridge.

title: The Time Machine
author: Wells, H. G.

title: The War of the Worlds
author: Wells, H. G.

title: The Island of Doctor Moreau
author: Wells, H. G.
rationale: Vivisection, cruelty, personhood; bridges science, ethics, and the monstrous.

title: The Invisible Man
author: Wells, H. G.
rationale: Power without accountability; links to ethics, identity, and social breakdown.

title: Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea
author: Verne, Jules
rationale: Technology wonder, isolation at sea; connects exploration + science clusters.

title: Journey to the Center of the Earth
author: Verne, Jules
rationale: Exploration, geology, unknown worlds; feeds science and the unknown cluster.

title: Works of Edgar Allan Poe Volume 1
author: Poe, Edgar Allan
rationale: Horror, madness, obsession; anchors dark psychology and gothic clusters.

title: Looking Backward 2000-1887
author: Bellamy, Edward
rationale: Utopian economics, equality; anchors utopia/dystopia domain.

title: Herland

rationale: Feminist utopia, social design; bridges gender constraint with utopian politics.

title: Treasure Island
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
rationale: Adventure, loyalty, moral ambiguity; connects to journey and exploration clusters.

title: The Republic
author: Plato
rationale: Justice, governance, virtue; key for power/governance thematic domain.

title: Symposium
author: Plato
rationale: Love, desire, beauty; links eros to ethics and social bonds clusters.

title: Nicomachean Ethics
author: Aristotle
rationale: Virtue ethics, flourishing; stabilizes good life conceptual clusters.

title: Meditations

title: The Prince
author: Machiavelli, Niccolò
rationale: Realpolitik, power; anchors governance and manipulation themes.

title: Leviathan

title: Second Treatise of Government
author: Locke, John
rationale: Rights, consent, property; supports liberal governance discourse.

title: On Liberty
author: Mill, John Stuart
rationale: Freedom, harm principle; intersects politics, individuality, morality.

title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart
rationale: Consequences, happiness calculus; links ethics to social policy.

title: Beyond Good and Evil
author: Nietzsche, Friedrich
rationale: Morality critique, will to power; drives existential/nihilism cluster.

title: Thus Spake Zarathustra
author: Nietzsche, Friedrich
rationale: Meaning-making, overcoming; complements existential and self-creation themes.

title: Essays, First Series
author: Emerson, Ralph Waldo

title: The Divine Comedy
author: Dante Alighieri
rationale: Moral cosmology, justice; links sin/virtue themes across eras.

title: Don Quixote
author: Cervantes, Miguel de

title: Les Misérables
author: Hugo, Victor
rationale: Justice, poverty, redemption; bridges social critique and moral philosophy.

title: The Count of Monte Cristo
author: Dumas, Alexandre
rationale: Revenge, identity, power; connects to justice and transformation clusters.

title: The Three Musketeers
author: Dumas, Alexandre
rationale: Honor, loyalty, politics; links adventure to governance/social networks.

title: Madame Bovary
author: Flaubert, Gustave
rationale: Desire, boredom, social constraint; cross-links with Austen/Wharton gender themes.

title: Father Goriot
author: Balzac, Honoré de
rationale: Social climbing, paternal sacrifice; strengthens ambition/class cluster.

title: The Red and the Black
author: Stendhal
rationale: Ambition, hypocrisy; reinforces class mobility and moral compromise.

title: Candide
author: Voltaire
rationale: Satire, optimism vs suffering; bridges philosophy with war/disaster themes.

title: The Odyssey
author: Homer
rationale: Homecoming, identity, trials; anchors epic journey and fate clusters.

title: The Iliad
author: Homer
rationale: War, honor, rage; anchors war/aftermath and heroism clusters.

title: The Aeneid
author: Virgil
rationale: Empire, duty, destiny; links governance with war and founding myths.

title: Faust Part 1
author: Goethe, Johann Wolfgang von
rationale: Knowledge, temptation, ambition; rich philosophical and moral themes.

title: Metamorphoses
author: Ovid
rationale: Transformation myths; feeds identity, change, and metamorphosis clusters.

title: Hamlet
author: Shakespeare, William
rationale: Indecision, revenge, madness; overlaps psychological torment clusters.

title: Macbeth
author: Shakespeare, William
rationale: Ambition, guilt, fate; links power and moral corruption themes.

title: King Lear
author: Shakespeare, William
rationale: Authority, family betrayal; connects governance with suffering and madness.

title: Othello
author: Shakespeare, William
rationale: Jealousy, race, manipulation; bridges identity, trust, and tragedy.

title: A Doll's House
author: Ibsen, Henrik
rationale: Gender roles, autonomy, marriage; core gender/constraint cluster.

title: Hedda Gabler
author: Ibsen, Henrik
rationale: Control, boredom, social pressure; complements psychological + constraint themes.

title: The Importance of Being Earnest
author: Wilde, Oscar
rationale: Social performance, hypocrisy; sharp satire for class and identity clusters.

title: The Cherry Orchard
author: Chekhov, Anton

title: On the Origin of Species
author: Darwin, Charles
rationale: Evolution, natural selection; anchors science discourse and nature clusters.

title: The Voyage of the Beagle
author: Darwin, Charles

title: Common Sense
author: Paine, Thomas
rationale: Revolutionary argumentation; connects rhetoric and political change clusters.

title: Rights of Man
author: Paine, Thomas
rationale: Rights discourse, legitimacy; complements Locke/Mill governance themes.

title: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman

title: The Communist Manifesto
author: Marx, Karl

title: The Federalist Papers
author: Hamilton, Alexander
rationale: Governance design, faction; strengthens power/governance thematic domain.

title: The Souls of Black Folk
author: Du Bois, W. E. B.

author: Washington, Booker T.

title: The Art of War
author: Sun Tzu

title: The Wealth of Nations
author: Smith, Adam

author: Montaigne, Michel de
